channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Analysis: A Cornered Putin Is More Dangerous Than Ever
item.description: In a major speech, he recast the war in Ukraine and made clear that it could spread.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: By calling up roughly 300,000 reservists to fight, and abandoning the objective of demilitarizing and “de-Nazifying” Ukraine, President Vladimir Putin of Russia acknowledged the reality and growing resistance of a unified Ukraine.

item.title: Trump Is Sued for Fraud By New York State A.G. Letitia James
item.description: The attorney general, Letitia James, is seeking to bar the Trump family from ever operating in New York again.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich, William K. Rashbaum and Ben Protess
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although the lawsuit against Donald J. Trump cannot include criminal charges, the former president could face substantial financial penalties.

item.title: Trump’s Lawyers Skirt Question of Declassification in Documents Case
item.description: The former president insists he shouldn’t have to state in a legal proceeding that he declassified the documents, while casting doubt on their status.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: No credible evidence has emerged to support former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he had a standing order to declassify everything he took from the Oval Office.

item.title: How the Car Market Is Shedding Light on a Key Inflation Question
item.description: How easily companies give up swollen profits could determine how easily the Federal Reserve can cool inflation. Dealerships offer clues.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Car dealers have been paying higher inventory costs but charging consumers even more, earning record profits.

item.title: How Will Interest Rate Increases Impact Inflation?
item.description: The Federal Reserve is raising interest rates to fight inflation. Some economists want more; some politicians want less. What’s the logic?

item.title: What Fed Rate Increases Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
item.description: Savers will benefit and borrowers can expect to pay more on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

item.title: TikTok’s Corn Kid Is Doing Just Fine
item.description: He went viral this summer for his love of corn. Now it’s back to business as usual: elementary school.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: A video of Tariq, 7, took off online when he shared his love of corn.

item.title: Suns and Mercury Owner Robert Sarver Plans to Sell Teams Amid Scandal
item.description: Robert Sarver, the majority owner of the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. teams in Phoenix, had been fined $10 million and suspended for using racist slurs and mistreating employees for years.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: Robert Sarver, who owns the Phoenix Suns, had been under investigation by the N.B.A. since November.

item.title: What Hemingway Left in Sloppy Joe’s Bar 80 Years Ago
item.description: The trove of items deposited in Key West, now part of a new archive at Penn State, includes four unpublished short stories, drafts of manuscripts and boxes of personal effects.
item.dc:creator: Robert K. Elder
item.media:credit: The Toby and Betty Bruce collection of Ernest Hemingway in the Penn State Special Collections Library
item.media:description: Ernest Hemingway served as a war correspondent during the Spanish Civil War.

item.title: In New Film, Former Employee Says Mario Batali Sexually Assaulted Her
item.description: A woman who worked for the chef comes forward with her account of a night at the Spotted Pig in Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Julia Moskin and Kim Severson
item.category: Batali: The Fall of a Superstar Chef (Movie)
item.media:description: It took five years after the #MeToo movement began for Eva DeVirgilis, who worked for Mario Batali, to go public with her account.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Bold Ventures,’ by Charlotte Van den Broeck
item.description: Charlotte Van den Broeck’s “Bold Ventures” is an idiosyncratic tour of architectural misfires, dotted with its author’s personal anxieties.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.category: Bold Ventures: Thirteen Tales of Architectural Tragedy (Book)
item.media:description: The twisted spire on the 400-year-old Church of St. Omer in Verchin, France, which embarrassed the chief mason who built it.

item.title: Three Paths Toward an Endgame for Putin’s War
item.description: But here are three possibilities.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man painting over the Russian flag in a recently recaptured Ukrainian village.

item.title: Inside the Completely Legal G.O.P. Plot to Destroy American Democracy
item.description: Imagine a legal January 6. It’s bureaucratic, boring, invisible, and it might actually succeed.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Harris and Michelle Cottle

item.title: Are There Better Places to Put Large Solar Farms Than These Forests?
item.description: For the great promise of renewable energy to be realized, states like Virginia must create an environment where solar, nature and people can peaceably coexist.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Popkin
item.media:credit: Melissa Lyttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twitty’s Creek Solar, a 134-acre, 15-megawatt installation along Highway 59, is the first solar project operating in Charlotte County, Va.

item.title: My Teachers Made Me Who I Am
item.description: In the midst of a debate about the content being presented in America’s schools, the equally pressing issue of how teachers teach is in danger of being lost.
item.dc:creator: Esau McCaulley

item.title: ‘We Can’t Let the Kids Go Outdoors’: Our New Reality on the West Coast
item.description: For children there, it isn’t a question of what you want to do outside; it’s whether it is even safe to leave the house.
item.dc:creator: Emma Pattee

item.title: Can Republicans Tax the Rich?
item.description: The continuing quest for a conservative policy reformation, and its continuing problems.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

item.title: After Dobbs: Feminism Beyond the Gender Binary
item.description: Jennifer Finney Boylan and Thomas Page McBee on what the feminist movement owes the trans community.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.media:credit: Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presses via Getty Images

item.title: The Border Crisis Could Still Be Biden’s Opportunity
item.description: But first it would help to admit that the border is not secure.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

item.title: A Shrinking Margin
item.description: Democrats lost ground with Hispanic voters in 2020. It doesn’t seem to have been a blip.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Trump in 2020 at a Latinos for Trump event in Phoenix.

item.title: How Border Politics Landed in Martha’s Vineyard
item.description: Two conservative governors are trying to make undocumented immigration a problem for blue states, not just red ones.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, Will Reid, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Matt Cosby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mother and daughter who were among the migrants flown to Martha’s Vineyard from Florida taking in the view last week as a ferry left the island.

item.title: ‘Serial’: Season 1
item.description: “Serial” is a podcast from the creators of “This American Life," hosted by Sarah Koenig. “Serial” tells one story — a true story — over the course of a season.
item.dc:creator: Serial Productions

item.title: Dates With a Book, Meals for Roller Skaters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking to celebrate a quiet birthday on your own? No problem.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson

item.title: ‘We’re on That Bus, Too’: In China, a Deadly Crash Triggers Covid Trauma
item.description: A bus heading to a quarantine facility crashed, killing 27. The Chinese public saw themselves in the victims: a country being held hostage by the government’s harsh policy.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:description: Waiting in line for a routine Covid test in Beijing. China has faced nearly three years of constant lockdowns, mass testing and quarantines under its “zero Covid” policy.

item.title: How MLB Authenticates Balls Like Aaron Judge’s 60th Homer
item.description: The ball from Aaron Judge’s 60th homer carried two markings — one of them invisible — authenticating it as the real deal. He will be pitched special baseballs for the rest of the season.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Home run balls like this one, which was hit in a game between the Yankees and the Milwaukee Brewers on Saturday, are authenticated as real and then get a special hologram with encoded data.

item.title: L.G.B.T.Q. Club Proposes a Compromise to Yeshiva University
item.description: The Modern Orthodox Jewish university in Manhattan had said it would halt the activities of all undergraduate clubs rather than sanction the gay student organization. The students say they will delay seeking recognition if the other clubs can resume.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Yeshiva University in New York is in a legal fight with an L.G.B.T.Q. student organization.

item.title: A Horse’s Collapse Rekindles Debate about Carriage Rides in New York’s Central Park
item.description: The horses have charmed tourists since the 19th century, but detractors say there is abuse and exploitation. Drivers say they are animal lovers doing their best.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.category: American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christina Hansen drives her horse, Oreo, across Manhattan.

item.title: Do Antidepressants Work for Severe PMS?
item.description: Premenstrual dysphoric disorder, or PMDD, is an extreme and often debilitating form of PMS that can be tricky to manage. Here’s what treatments work.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Rabkin Peachman
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: IUD Insertion: What to Know and Expect
item.description: Intrauterine devices are highly effective, but some women find insertion painful. Here’s how to prepare.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
item.description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
item.dc:creator: Jacquelynn Kerubo

item.title: Are Plan B and Body Weight Interconnected?
item.description: Researchers have looked into why and how weight influences emergency contraception but have come up against several unknowns. Here’s what we know.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Dani Blum

item.title: How to Recognize and Treat Perimenopause Symptoms
item.description: We break down the signs, causes and treatment options for five common symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum and Monica Garwood

item.title: The Artist Who Throws Newton a Curve
item.description: The Orange County Museum of Art inaugurates its new building with a tribute to Fred Eversley, an unheralded pioneer of the Light and Space movement.
item.dc:creator: Hilarie M. Sheets
item.media:credit: Elliott Jerome Brown Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sculptor Fred Eversley alongside one of his parabolic lenses that is installed on the ground floor of his five-story building in Manhattan’s SoHo neighborhood.

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
